{{Other uses|Jacob's Ladder (disambiguation)}} [[Image:Jacobs Ladder toy.JPG|thumb|upright|A Jacob's Ladder unfolded
[[Media:Jacob's Ladder toy demonstration.ogg|Watch toy in action]] ([[Theora|Ogg Theora]] format, 1.7 MB) ([[:Image:Jacob's Ladder toy demonstration.ogg|clip info]])]] A '''Jacob's ladder''' (also '''magic tablets''', '''Chinese blocks''', and '''klick-klack toy'''Frauenfelder, Mark (2011). ''Make: Technology On Your Time, Vol. 26: Roll Your Own'', p.148. O'Reilly Media. {{ISBN|9781449397593}}.) is a [[Folk culture|folk]] [[toy]] consisting of [[toy block|blocks]] of wood held together by strings or [[ribbon]]s. It is "a toy that does some very weird things."Murphy, Pat; Lambertson, Lori; and Tesler, Pearl (2004). ''The Math Explorer: Games and Activities for Middle School Youth Groups'', p.109 & 116. Exploratorium. {{ISBN|9781559535403}}. When the ladder is held at one end, blocks appear to cascade down the strings. This effect is a [[optical illusion|visual illusion]] which is the result of one block after another flipping over. It may be considered a [[kinetic illusion]], where the blocks appear to change position when they do not. Its name ''Jacob's Ladder'' comes from the biblical [[Jacob's Ladder (Bible)|ladder to heaven]], mentioned in Genesis 28:12. Of unknown origin, the earliest known review of the Jacob's Ladder is an 1889 ''[[Scientific American]]'' article which tells how it is built and works: {{quote|The simple toy ... is very illusive in action. When the upper block is grasped by the edges ... and turned so as to lift the second block in the series to the same height, the upper end of the second block falls into an inverted position, and appears to pass downward on the other members of the series, first upon one side of the ladder and then upon the other until it reaches the bottom. But this effect is only apparent, as the second block in reality only falls back into its original position in the series; but in the operation it becomes reversed, what was before the lower end becoming the upper end, the front having exchanged places with the back. This change of position of the second member brings it parallel with the third block, which is then released, and the third member drops over onto the fourth, when the fifth block is released, and so on throughout the entire series.|"Jacob's Ladder", ''Scientific American'', Vol. 61, No. 15 (October 1889)[https://archive.org/stream/scientific-american-1889-10-12/scientific-american-v61-n15-1889-10-12#page/n3/mode/2up Scientific American, October 12, 1889, page 227.]}} ==Construction== [[File:Jacob's Ladder 2.jpg|thumb|The mechanism of a Jacob's Ladder, "Fig. 2"]] An arrangement of interlaced ribbons allows each block to act as if hinged to the next one at either of its two ends. The same mechanism is used in the 1980s toy [[Rubik's Magic]],"[http://www.mathematische-basteleien.de/magics.htm Rubik's Magic]", ''Mathematische-Basteleien.de''. "The first impression is that every piece has two hinges like the Jacob's ladder toy. This is partly right. The mechanism is more complicated however." Accessed May, 2016. but with plastic filaments run diagonally across squares, with the result that the squares can hinge along either of two ''adjacent'' sides. {{quote|In Fig. 2 are shown the three upper blocks of the series, 1, 2, and 3, and their connecting tapes, the blocks being represented as transparent and separated from each other a short distance to show the arrangement of the connections. Block 1 has attached to it three tapes, ''a'', ''b'', ''b''. The tape, ''a'', is attached to the face of the block at the center, at the upper end, and extends over the rounded end of this block and under the rounded end of block 2. The tapes, ''b'', ''b'', are attached to the face of block 1, extending downwardly under the lower end of this block and upwardly over the upper end of block 2. The tape, ''a'', which is attached to the center of the upper face of block 2, extends over the end of this block, downward underneath, the block, and over the upper end of block 3, where it is secured. This arrangement of tapes is observed throughout the entire series.|''Scientific American''}} ==Origin== The toy has been described as originating in China,Nourse, James G. (1981/1986). ''Simple Solutions to Rubik's Magic'', p.6. Bantam. {{ISBN|9780552118477}}/{{ISBN|9780553267686}}. as being found in [[King Tut]]'s [[KV62|tomb]],Baljeu, Janet (2012). ''Downloading Spirit: Babushka'', p.38. Xlibris. {{ISBN|9781469157665}}. "Then there is a Jacob Ladder's toy which was found in the tomb of Tutankhamun.""[http://www.woodcraftarts.com/jacob.htm Jacob's Ladder]", ''WoodCraftArts.com''. "Legend has it that one was found in King Tut's tomb". though unmentioned in its inventory, and as one of the few toys allowed on Sunday by Puritans in colonial America,Judah, J. C. (2008). ''The Legends of Brunswick County: Ghosts, Pirates, Indians and Colonial North Carolina'', p.136. Lulu.com. {{ISBN|9780615175867}}. "Because it was a 'nice quiet toy'."{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}} "but the true origin of the toy remains a mystery." Many slight variants have been patented in the United States, one from the 1940s having in one block an indentation to hold a penny, which then appeared to dis- and re-appear. The Japanese polymath [[Hiraga Gennai]] (1729–1779) constructed a Jacob's ladder which later came to be called "Gennai's Wondrous Click-clack" (''Gennai no fushigina katakata'', 源内の不思議なカタカタ).{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} ==See also== *[[Chinese block]] *[[Jacob's ladder (string figure)]] *[[Rhombille tiling]] * [[Pocket Cube]] * [[Rubik's Cube]] * [[Rubik's Revenge]] * [[Professor's Cube]] * [[V-Cube 6]] * [[V-Cube 7]] * [[V-Cube 8]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Jacobs Ladder (toy)}} *"[https://www.lockhaven.edu/~dsimanek/TTT-rings/rings.htm Toys, Tricks and Teasers: Kinetic Illusion Toys]", ''Donald Simanek's Pages at lockhaven.edu''. {{DEFAULTSORT:Jacob's Ladder (Toy)}} [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:Traditional toys]] [[Category:Wooden toys]]

[[File:Krummträ.JPG|thumb|Knee timbers in boat building]] In [[woodworking]], a '''knee''' is a natural or cut, curved piece of wood.<ref>Oxford English Dictionary Second Edition on CD-ROM (v. 4.0) Oxford University Press 2009</ref> Knees, sometimes called ships knees, are a common form of bracing in [[boat building]] and occasionally in [[timber framing]]. A [[rafter|knee rafter]] in carpentry is a bent rafter used to gain head room in an attic.
==Strength characteristics== Wood is a highly [[anisotropic]] material (its strength varies considerably with the direction of applied force, i.e. parallel, radial, or tangential to the grain). Because wood is strongest when loaded in tension or compression along the grain, the best knees are those in which the wood grain follows the bend. For a knee with relatively little bend, it may be possible to cut the knee out of a single straight-grained board and still achieve sufficient strength. However, with increasing bend this method becomes problematic since more and more of the knee is aligned across the grain and is therefore considerably weaker. A knee laid out this way might easily snap in two under hand pressure alone, even if it is generously sized. In boat joinery constantly subject to shock and [[fatigue (material)|fatigue]] loading this method is unsuitable.
To avoid this issue knees requiring sharper curves are made using methods which ensure that the wood grain and direction of load are closely aligned. This can be achieved by [[steam bending]], [[laminating]], or selecting a natural crook with matching grain - a "grown knee". Grown knees are generally considered as the "best" method among boat builders and have a strong traditions associated with their use, but they may not achieve the same strength as a good laminated knee.
==Types== '''Bent''' - Bent knees<ref>John Griffiths, mfg.. Bent timber ships and universal wood bending machinery. Philadelphia 1876. https://books.google.com/books?id=d-0OAAAAYAAJ</ref> are formed by plasticizing the wood to make it flexible via boiling, steaming, or microwaving (for small components). While still hot, the wood can be bent into a shape suitable for the location - either on a form or by forcing and securing it directly into the final service location. Steam-bending is a time-honored method for shaping boat frames, but it does weaken the wood slightly, it can leave residual stresses which may cause breakage or spring-back over time, and it is limited in the degree of bend which it can achieve, particularly for thick members. Also, not all species of wood steam bend well.
'''Laminated''' - Laminated knees are formed by coating thin, flexible strips of wood with adhesive, layering them to achieve the required thickness, then forcing the desired bend into the layup and securing it until the adhesive sets. Laminated knees are very strong and can be made in shapes which would be difficult to achieve using other methods, but they require time for the adhesive to cure, they are messier to construct, and they must use a jig or fixture to secure them until the adhesive cures.
'''Grown''' - The term "grown knees" refers to any knee which is made from a natural crook or bend in a tree. Grown knees can be taken from several locations within a tree, with the most common being the intersection of the trunk and a large branch{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}}, crotches, and the roots. The roots are a particularly useful source as the root structure of many species of trees naturally spreads out laterally just beneath the ground in order to help anchor the tree. This provides a fairly reliable source of approximately 90 degree crooks which may be impossible to find in other portions of the tree. In order to obtain this raw material for knees builders may dig up a stump in its entirety, as unlike other portions of the tree, it is impossible to judge the quality and quantity of available material in the roots as they are underground. Once the stump has been dug up the knees can be sawn or split from suitable natural crooks. However, knees sawn from a stump can quickly dull tools used to shape and finish them - as the roots grow they envelop small particles of soil and rock, which acts as an embedded abrasive and accelerates the wear of edged tools. For species of wood with appropriate splitting characteristics, such as oak, the stump can be split into wedges, with one large root on each wedge; each wedge is then carved into a [[rib]] for a small boat. In principle [[tree shaping]] could be used to grow a tree into the desired shape.
==Terminology== A sharp bend in a piece of wood is also called "cranked". Commonly used in shipbuilding known as ship’s knee for their advantage of reducing the encroachment into the usable space of the structure since there is no [[spandrel]]. Also knee rafter increases the usable space in an attic by creating a kneewall-like space.
A ship’s knee has two parts called the arm (shorter) and a body (longer). The outside surfaces come to a corner, (typically 90 degrees in buildings) called the heel. The inside surface retains its natural shape and the curve is called the bosom. The thickness between the heel and bosom is the throat. The ends of the arm and body are the toes.
The names of ship’s knees are based on their position:<ref>Theodore Delavan Wilson. ''An Outline of Ship Building, Theoretical and Practical''. New York: John Wiley & Son, 15 Astor Place, 1873. https://books.google.com/books?id=q8BGvRlCZ8cC</ref><ref>Newman Gee, ''Joiner’s Quarterly'' #36, 17, 19</ref> * Hanging knee, the arm is down; * Standing~, the arm is up; * Lodging~, the arm is sideways; * Boson~ or lap~, (unclear); * Quarter~, quarter sawn thus smaller but without the pith (center of the tree rings) so less prone to checking; * Dagger~ In shipbuilding, typically a hanging knee set slightly off diagonally to clear an obstruction such as a gunport in a fighting ship. From "Building the Wooden Fighting Ship" Dodds and Moore 1984
Knees can be blind pegged with foxtail wedges on both ends or bolted in place.
==Favored species of wood== Due to tradition, ease of workability, strength and durability characteristics, some species of wood are particularly prized for making knees. [[Tamarack]] (also known as [[hackmatack]]) stumps are among the preferred [[softwood]] species for grown knees, while [[white oak]], [[live oak]], and [[elm]] are preferred for [[hardwoods]] for bent knees due to their ease of steam bending.
==See also== * [[Boat building]] * [[Ship building]] * [[Steam bending]] * [[Timber framing]]

'''Langbeinites''' are a family of crystalline substances based on the structure of [[langbeinite]] with general formula M<sub>2</sub>M<sup>'</sup><sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, where M is a large univalent cation such as [[potassium]], [[rubidium]], [[caesium]], or ammonium), and M<sup>'</sup> is a small divalent cation for example ([[magnesium]], [[calcium]], [[manganese]], [[iron]], [[cobalt]], [[nickel]], [[copper]], [[zinc]] or [[cadmium]]). The sulfate group, SO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>, can be substituted by other tetrahedral anions with a double negative charge such as [[tetrafluoroberyllate]] BeF<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>, [[selenate]] (SeO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>), [[chromate]] (CrO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>), [[molybdate]] (MO<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup>), or [[tungstate]]s. Although [[monofluorophosphate]]s are predicted, they have not been described. By redistributing charges other anions with the same shape such as [[phosphate]] also form langbeinite structures. In these the M<sup>'</sup> atom must have a greater charge to balance the extra three negative charges.
At higher temperatures the crystal structure is cubic P2<sub>1</sub>3.<ref name="Norberg"/> However, the crystal structure may change to lower symmetries at lower temperatures, for example, P2<sub>1</sub>, P1, or P2<sub>1</sub>2<sub>1</sub>2<sub>1</sub>.<ref name="Norberg"/> Usually this temperature is well below room temperature, but in a few cases the substance must be heated to acquire the cubic structure.
==Crystal structure== The crystal structures of langbeinites consist of a network of oxygen vertex-connected tetrahedral polyanions (such as sulfate) and distorted metal ion-oxygen octahedra.<ref name=Kum15/> The unit cell contains four formula units. In the cubic form the tetrahedral anions are slightly rotated from the main crystal axes. When cooled, this rotation disappears and the tetrahedra align, resulting in lower energy as well as lower crystal symmetry.
==Examples== Sulfates include dithallium dicadmium sulfate,<ref name="Guelylah2000">{{cite journal|last=Guelylah|first=A.|author2=G. Madariaga |author3=W. Morgenroth |author4=M. I. Aroyo |author5=T. Breczewski |author6=E. H. Bocanegra |year=2000|title=X-ray structure determination of the monoclinic (121 K) and orthorhombic (85 K) phases of langbeinite-type dithallium dicadmium sulfate|journal=Acta Crystallographica Section B|volume=56|issue=6|pages=921–935|doi=10.1107/S0108768100009514}}</ref> Dirubidium dicadmium sulfate<ref name="Guelylah2003">{{cite journal|last=Guelylah|first=Abderrahim|author2=Gotzon Madariaga |year=2003|title=Dirubidium dicadmium sulfate at 293 K|journal=Acta Crystallographica Section C|volume=59|issue=5|pages=i32–i34|doi=10.1107/S0108270103007479}}</ref> dipotassium dicadmium sulfate,<ref name="Guelylah1996b">{{cite journal|last=Guelylah|first=A.|author2=M. I. Aroyo |author3=J. M. Pérez-Mato |year=1996|title=Microscopic distortion and order parameter in langbeinite K<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Phase Transitions|volume=59|issue=1–3|pages=155–179|doi=10.1080/01411599608220042}}</ref> dithallium manganese sulfate.<ref name="Zemann1957">{{cite journal|last=Zemann|first=Anna|author2=J. Zemann |year=1957|title=Die Kristallstruktur von Langbeinit, K<sub>2</sub>Mg<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Acta Crystallographica|volume=10|issue=6|pages=409–413|doi=10.1107/S0365110X57001346}}</ref> dirubidium dicalcium trisulfate.<ref name="Boujelben2007">{{cite journal|last=Boujelben|first=Mohamed|author2=Mohamed Toumi |author3=Tahar Mhiri |year=2007|title=Langbeinite-type Rb<sub>2</sub>Ca<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Acta Crystallographica Section E|volume=63|issue=7|pages=i157|doi=10.1107/S1600536807027043}}</ref>
Selenates include diammonium dimanganese selenate.<ref name="Norberg"/> A diammonium dicadmium selenate langbeinite could not be crystallised from water, but a trihydrate exists.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Martínez|first1=M.L.|last2=Rodriguez|first2=A.|last3=Mestres|first3=L.|last4=Solans|first4=X.|last5=Bocanegra|first5=E.H.|title=Synthesis, crystal structure, and thermal studies of (NH4)2Cd2(SeO4)3·3H2O|journal=Journal of Solid State Chemistry|date=November 1990|volume=89|issue=1|pages=88–93|doi=10.1016/0022-4596(90)90297-B|bibcode = 1990JSSCh..89...88M }}</ref>
Chromate based langbeinites include dicaesium dimanganese chromate.<ref name="Norberg"/>
Molybdates include Rb<sub>2</sub>Co<sub>2</sub>(MoO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>.<ref name="Norberg"/> Potassium members are absent, as are zinc and copper containing solids, which all crystallize in different forms. Manganese, magenesium, cadmium and some nickel double molydates exist as langbeinites.<ref name="Солодовникова">{{cite journal|last=Солодовникова|first=С.Ф.|author2=Солодовникова, В.А. |year=1997|title=Новый тип строения в морфотропном ряду A<sup>+</sup><sub>2</sub>M<sup>+</sup><sub>2</sub>(MoO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>: кристаллическая структура Rb<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>2</sub>(MoO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=ЖУРНАЛ структур. химии|volume=38|issue=5|pages=914–921|language=Russian|url=http://jsc.niic.nsc.ru/JSC/jsc_rus/1997-t38/n5/V38_N5_12.pdf}}</ref>
Double tungstates of the form A<sub>2</sub>B<sub>2</sub>(WO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> are predicted to exist in the langbeinite form.<ref name="Kiselyova"/>
Examples with tetrafluroberyllate include dipotassium dimanganese tetrafluoroberyllate K<sub>2</sub>Mn<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>,<ref name="Guelylah1996">{{cite journal|last=Guelylah|first=A.|author2=T. Breczewski |author3=G. Madariaga |year=1996|title=A New Langbeinite: Dipotassium Dimanganese Tetrafluoroberyllate|journal=Acta Crystallographica Section C|volume=52|issue=12|pages=2951–2954|doi=10.1107/S0108270196008827}}</ref>
Other tetrafluoroberyllates may include Rb<sub>2</sub>Mg<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Tl<sub>2</sub>Mg<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Tl<sub>2</sub>Mn<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Rb<sub>2</sub>Ni<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Tl<sub>2</sub>Ni<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Rb<sub>2</sub>Zn<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Tl<sub>2</sub>Zn<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Cs<sub>2</sub>Ca<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Rb<sub>2</sub>Ca<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> RbCsMnCd(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Cs<sub>2</sub>MnCd(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> RbCsCd<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Cs<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. Tl<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> KRbMnCd(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> K<sub>2</sub>MnCd(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Rb<sub>2</sub>MnCd(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Rb<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> RbCsCo<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Co<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> K<sub>2</sub>Co<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Rb<sub>2</sub>Co<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Tl<sub>2</sub>Co<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> RbCsMn<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Cs<sub>2</sub>Mn<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> RbCsZn<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Mg<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Mn<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Ni<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Zn<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> KRbMg<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> K<sub>2</sub>Mg<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. KRbMn<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> K<sub>2</sub>Mn<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> K<sub>2</sub>Ni<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> K<sub>2</sub>Zn<sub>2</sub>(BeF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name="Pies1973">{{Cite book|last=Pies|first=W.|author2=A. Weiss |year=1973|volume=7a|pages=91–103|doi=10.1007/10201462_9|chapter=A458, I.1.3 Complex fluorides and fluorine double salts|title=Key Elements: F, Cl, Br, I|series=Landolt-Börnstein - Group III Condensed Matter|isbn=978-3-540-06166-3}}</ref>
The phosphate containing langbeinites were found in 1972 with the discovery of KTi<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, and since then a few more phosphates that also contain titanium have been found such as Na<sub>2</sub>FeTi(PO<sub>4</sub>), Na<sub>2</sub>CrTi(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. By substituting metals in A<sub>2</sub>MTi(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, A from K, Rb, Cs, and M from Cr, Fe or V other langbeinites are made. The [[NASICON]]-type structure competes for these kinds of phosphates, so not all possibilities are langbeinites.<ref name="Norberg"/> Other phosphate based substances include K<sub>2</sub>YTi(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> K<sub>2</sub>ErTi(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> K<sub>2</sub>YbTi(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, K<sub>2</sub>CrTi(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name="Norberg">{{cite journal|last=Norberg|first=Stefan T.|year=2002|title=New phosphate langbeinites, K<sub>2</sub>MTi(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (M = Er, Yb or Y), and an alternative description of the langbeinite framework|journal=Acta Crystallographica B|volume=58|issue=5|pages=743–749|pmid=12324686|doi=10.1107/S0108768102013782|pmc=2391006}}</ref> K<sub>2</sub>AlSn(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name="Li2011">{{cite journal|last=Li|first=Hai-Yan|author2=Dan Zhao |year=2011|title=A new langbeinite-type phosphate: K<sub>2</sub>AlSn(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Acta Crystallographica Section E|volume=67|issue=10|pages=i56|doi=10.1107/S1600536811037263|pmid=22058680|pmc=3201338}}</ref> Rb<sub>2</sub>YbTi(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>.<ref name="Gustafsson2006">{{cite journal|last=Gustafsson|first=Joacim C. M.|author2=Stefan T. Norberg |author3=Göran Svensson |year=2006|title=The langbeinite type Rb<sub>2</sub>TiY(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Acta Crystallographica Section E|volume=62|issue=7|pages=i160–i162|doi=10.1107/S1600536806021635}}</ref> Sodium barium diiron tris-(phosphate) NaBaFe<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> is yet another variation with the same structure but differently charged ions.<ref name="Hidouri2008">{{cite journal|last=Hidouri|first=Mourad|author2=Hasna Jerbi |author3=Mongi Ben Amara |year=2008|title=The iron phosphate NaBaFe2(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Acta Crystallographica Section E|volume=64|issue=8|pages=i51|doi=10.1107/S1600536808023040|pmid=21202994|pmc=2961906}}</ref> Most phosphates of this kind of formula do not form langbeinites, instead crystallise in the NASICON structure with archetype Na<sub>3</sub>Zr<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)(SiO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>.<ref name="Norberg"/>
A langbeinite with [[arsenate]] is known to exist by way of K<sub>2</sub>ScSn(AsO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>.<ref name="Harrison2010">{{cite journal|last=Harrison|first=William T. A.|year=2010|title=K<sub>2</sub>ScSn(AsO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>: an arsenate-containing langbeinite|journal=Acta Crystallographica Section C|volume=66|issue=7|pages=i82–i84|doi=10.1107/S0108270110021670|pmid=20603547}}</ref>
==Properties==
===Physical properties=== Lanbeinite crystals can show [[ferroelectric]] or [[ferroelastic]] properties.<ref name="Norberg"/> Diammonium dicadmium sulfate identified by Jona and Pepinsky<ref name="Jona1956">{{cite journal|last=Jona|first=F.|author2=R. Pepinsky |year=1956|title=Ferroelectricity in the Langbeinite System|journal=Physical Review|volume=103|issue=4|pages=1126|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.103.1126|bibcode=1956PhRv..103.1126J}}</ref> with a unit cell size of 10.35 Å becomes ferroelectric when the temperature drops below 95K.<ref name="McDowell1975">{{cite journal|last=McDowell|first=C.A.|author2=P. Raghunathan |author3=R. Srinivasan |year=1975|title=Proton N.M.R. study of the dynamics of the ammonium ion in ferroelectric langbeinite, (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Molecular Physics|volume=29|issue=3|pages=815–824|doi=10.1080/00268977500100721|bibcode=1975MolPh..29..815M}}</ref> The phase transition temperature is not fixed, and can vary depending on the crystal or history of temperature change. So for example the phase transition in diammonium dicadmium sulfate can occur between 89 and 95 K.<ref name="Moriyoshi">{{cite web|url=http://ir.lib.hiroshima-u.ac.jp/metadb/up/ZZT00003/200703/Ferroelectrics_337_85.pdf|title=Structural Study of Langbeinite-type (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Cd(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>) Crystal in the High Temperature Phase|last=Moriyoshi|first=C. |author2=E. Magome |author3=K. Itoh|date=28 March 2007|website=IMF-11|accessdate=24 June 2013}}</ref> Under pressure the highest phase transition temperature increases. ∂T/∂P = 0.0035 degrees/bar. At 824 bars there is a triple point with yet another transition diverging at a slope of ∂T/∂P = 0.103 degrees/bar.<ref name="Glogarová1972">{{cite journal|last=Glogarová|first=M.|author2=C. Frenzel |author3=E. Hegenbarth |year=1972|title=The Behaviour of (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> under Pressure|journal=Physica Status Solidi B|volume=53|issue=1|pages=369–372|doi=10.1002/pssb.2220530139|bibcode=1972PSSBR..53..369G}}</ref> For dipotassium dimanganese sulfate pressure causes the transition to rise at the rate of 6.86 °C/kbar. The latent heat of the transition is 456 cal/mol.<ref name="Hikita1979">{{cite journal|last=Hikita|first=Tomoyuki|author2=Makoto Kitabatake |author3=Takuro Ikeda |year=1979|title=Hydrostatic Pressure Effect on the Phase Transition of K<sub>2</sub>Mn<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Journal of the Physical Society of Japan|volume=46|issue=2|pages=695–696|doi=10.1143/JPSJ.46.695|bibcode=1979JPSJ...46..695H}}</ref>
Dithallium dicadmium sulfate was shown to be ferroelectric in 1972.<ref name="B̌rzina1972">{{cite journal|last=B̌rzina|first=B.|author2=M. Glogarová |year=1972|title=New ferroelectric langbeinite Tl<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Physica Status Solidi A|volume=11|issue=1|pages=K39–K42|doi=10.1002/pssa.2210110149|bibcode= 1972PSSAR..11...39.}}</ref>
Dipotassium dicadmium sulfate is [[thermoluminescent]] with stronger outputs of light at 350 and 475 K. This light output can be boosted forty times with a trace amount of samarium.<ref name="Deshmukh1986">{{cite journal|last=Deshmukh|first=B. T.|author2=S. V. Bodade |author3=S. V. Moharil |year=1986|title=Thermoluminescence of K<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Physica Status Solidi A|volume=98|issue=1|pages=239–246|doi=10.1002/pssa.2210980127|bibcode=1986PSSAR..98..239D}}</ref> Dipotassium dimagnesium sulfate doped with dysprosium develops [[thermoluminescence]] and [[mechanoluminescence]] after being irradiated with gamma rays.<ref name="Panigrahi2003">{{cite journal|last=Panigrahi|first=A. K.|author2=Dhoble, S. J. |author3=Kher, R. S. |author4=Moharil, S. V. |year=2003|title=Thermo and mechanoluminescence of Dy<sup>3+</sup> activated K<sub>2</sub>Mg<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> phosphor|journal=Physica Status Solidi A|volume=198|issue=2|pages=322–328|doi=10.1002/pssa.200306605|bibcode=2003PSSAR.198..322P}}</ref> Since gamma rays occur naturally, this radiation induced thermoluminescence can be used to date [[evaporite]]s in which langbeinite can be a constituent.<ref name="Léost2001">{{cite journal|last=Léost|first=I.|author2=Féraud, G. |author3=Blanc-Valleron, M. M. |author4=Rouchy, J. M. |year=2001|title=First absolute dating of Miocene Langbeinite evaporites by <sup>40</sup>Ar/<sup>39</sup>Ar laser step-heating: [K<sub>2</sub>Mg<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>] Stebnyk Mine (Carpathian Foredeep Basin)|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|volume=28|issue=23|pages=4347–4350|doi=10.1029/2001GL013477 |bibcode=2001GeoRL..28.4347L}}</ref>
At higher temperatures the crystals take on [[Cubic crystal system|cubic form]], whereas at the lowest temperatures they can transform to an [[Orthorhombic crystal system|orthorhombic crystal group]]. For some types there are two more phases, and as the crystal is cooled it goes from cubic, to [[Monoclinic crystal system|monoclinic]], to [[Triclinic crystal system|triclinic]] to orthorhombic. This change to higher symmetry on cooling is very unusual in solids.<ref name="Franke1975">{{cite journal|last=Franke|first=V.|author2=E. Hegenbarth |author3=B. Březina |year=1975|title=Specific heat measurement on Tl<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Physica Status Solidi A|volume=28|issue=1|pages=K77–K80|doi=10.1002/pssa.2210280165|bibcode=1975PSSAR..28...77F}}</ref> For some langbeinites only the cubic form is known, but that may be because it has not been studied at low enough temperatures yet. Those that have three phase transitions go through these [[crystallographic point group]]s: P2<sub>1</sub>3 – P2<sub>1</sub> – P1 – P2<sub>1</sub>2<sub>1</sub>2<sub>1</sub>, whereas the single phase change crystals only have P2<sub>1</sub>3 – P2<sub>1</sub>2<sub>1</sub>2<sub>1</sub>.
K<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> has a transition temperature above room temperature, so that it is ferroelectric in standard conditions. The orthorhombic cell size is a=10.2082 Å, b=10.2837 Å, c=10.1661 Å.<ref name="Abrahams1977">{{cite journal|last=Abrahams|first=S. C.|author2=J. L. Bernstein |year=1977|title=Piezoelectric langbeinite-type K<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>: Room temperature crystal structure and ferroelastic transformation|journal=The Journal of Chemical Physics|volume=67|issue=5|page=2146|doi=10.1063/1.435101|bibcode=1977JChPh..67.2146A}}</ref>
Where the crystals change phase there is a discontinuity in the heat capacity. The transitions may show thermal hysteresis.<ref name="Cao1993">{{cite journal|last=Cao|first=Hongjie|author2=N. Kent Dalley |author3=Juliana Boerio-Goates |year=1993|title=Calorimetric and structural studies of langbeinite-type Tl<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Ferroelectrics|volume=146|issue=1|pages=45–56|doi=10.1080/00150199308008525}}</ref>
Different cations can be substituted so that for example K<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Tl<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> can form solid solutions for all ratios of thallium and potassium. Properties such as the phase transition temperature and unit cell sizes vary smoothly with the composition.<ref name="Sutera1981">{{cite journal|last=Sutera|first=A.|author2=K. Nassau |author3=S. C. Abrahams |year=1981|title=Phase-transition variation with composition in solid solutions of K<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> with Tl<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Journal of Applied Crystallography|volume=14|issue=5|pages=297–299|doi=10.1107/S0021889881009412}}</ref>
Langeinites containing transition metals can be coloured. For example, cobalt langbeinite shows a broad absorption around 555 nm due to the cobalt <sup>4</sup>T<sub>1g</sub>(F)<big>→</big><sup>4</sup>T<sub>1g</sub>(P) electronic transition.<ref name="Percival1990">{{cite journal|last=Percival|first=M. J. L.|year=1990|title=Optical Absorption Spectroscopy of Doped Materials: The P2<sub>1</sub>3-P2<sub>1</sub>2<sub>1</sub>2<sub>1</sub> Phase Transition in K<sub>2</sub>(Cd<sub>0.98</sub>Co<sub>0.02</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Mineralogical Magazine|volume=54|issue=377|pages=525–535|doi=10.1180/minmag.1990.054.377.01}}</ref>
The enthalpy of formation (ΔfHm) for solid (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> at 298.2K is −3031.74±0.08 kJ/mol, and for K<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> it is －3305.52±0.17 kJ/mol.<ref name="Zhou">{{cite journal|last=Zhou|first=Ya-Ping|author2=Zhang Rui |author3=Wan Hong-Wen |author4=Zhan Zheng-Kun |author5=Xu Ming-Fei |date=March 2001|title=Thermochemical Studies on the Langbeinite-Type Double Sulfate Salts，(NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and K<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Acta Physico-Chimica Sinica|volume=17|issue=3|page=247|doi=10.3866/PKU.WHXB20010312|url=http://www.whxb.pku.edu.cn/EN/abstract/abstract24330.shtml|language=Chinese}}</ref>

I.|last2=Asabina|first2=E. A.|last3=Markin|first3=A. V.|last4=Alekseev|first4=A. A.|last5=Smirnova|first5=N. N.|title=Thermodynamic investigation of Rb2FeTi(PO4)3 phosphate of langbeinite structure|journal=Journal of Thermal Analysis and Calorimetry|date=22 February 2016|doi=10.1007/s10973-016-5319-8|volume=124|issue=3|pages=1535–1544}}</ref> |511.56 |9.8892 | |Na<sub>2</sub>FeTi(PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub> has NZP structure<ref name="asabina09"/> |- |KBaMgTi(PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=pet>{{cite journal|last1=Pet’kov|first1=V. I.|last2=Alekseev|first2=A. A.|last3=Asabina|first3=E. A.|last4=Borovikova|first4=E. Yu.|last5=Koval’skii|first5=A. M.|title=Synthesis, structure formation, and thermal expansion of A+M2+MgE4+(PO4)3|journal=Russian Journal of Inorganic Chemistry|date=6 August 2017|volume=62|issue=7|pages=870–878|doi=10.1134/S0036023617070178}}</ref> |485.51 |9.914 | |KSrMgTi crystallises in kosnarite form |- |KPbMgTi(PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=pet/> |555.39 |9.8540 | |KSrMgTi in kosnarite form |- |RbBaMgTi(PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=pet/> | |9.954 |531.88 |CsBa does not form |- |RbPbMgTi(PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=pet/> |601.76 |9.9090 | |CsPb does not form |- |KSrMgZr(PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=pet/> |479.16 |10.165 | | |- |KPbMgZr(PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=pet/> |598.74 |10.111 | | |- |KBaMgZr(PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=pet/> |528.87 |10.106 | | |- |RbSrMgZr(PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=pet/> |525.53 |10.218 | | |- |RbPbMgZr(PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=pet/> |645.11 |10.178 | | |- |RbBaMgZr(PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=pet/> |575.24 |10.178 | | |- |CsSrMgZr(PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=pet/> |572.97 |10.561 | |over 1250 °C forms kosnarite phase |- |}
==Vanadates== The orthovanadates have four formula per cell, with a slightly distorted cell that has [[orthorhombic]] symmetry. {|class="wikitable" | |formula weight |comment |colspan=3|Cell dimensions Å |Volume |density |refractive |- |Formula |g/mol |symmetries |a |b |c | | |index |- |LiBaCr<sub>2</sub>(VO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=nabar80>{{cite journal|last1=Nabar|first1=M. A.|last2=Phanasgaonkar|first2=D. S.|title=Preparation and X-ray powder diffraction studies of triple orthovanadates having langbeinite structure|journal=Journal of Applied Crystallography|date=1 October 1980|volume=13|issue=5|pages=450–451|doi=10.1107/s0021889880012514}}</ref> |593.08 |Orthorhombic |9.98 |10.52 |9.51 |998 |4.02 |- |NaBaCr<sub>2</sub>(VO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=nabar80/> |609.13 |Orthorhombic |9.99 |10.52 |9.53 |1002 |4.09 |- |AgBaCr<sub>2</sub>(VO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=nabar80/> |694.00 |Orthorhombic |10.02 |10.53 |9.53 |1005 |4.62 |- |}
==Arsenates== {|class="wikitable" !substance !formula weight !unit cell edge Å !density |- |K<sub>2</sub>ScSn(AsO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Harrison|first1=William T. A.|title=K2ScSn(AsO4)3 : an arsenate-containing langbeinite|journal=Acta Crystallographica Section C|date=17 June 2010|volume=66|issue=7|pages=i82–i84|doi=10.1107/S0108270110021670|pmid=20603547}}</ref> |658.62 |10.3927 | |- |Zr<sub>2</sub>NH<sub>4</sub>(AsO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>.H<sub>2</sub>O<ref name=rouse>{{Cite book|last1=Rouse|first1=Jessica|title=Synthesis and Characterisation of Lanthanide and Other Inorganic Framework Materials|url=http://eprints.soton.ac.uk/173801/1.hasCoversheetVersion/FINAL_AH_CHECK.pdf|publisher=University of Southampton, Faculty of Engineering, Science and Mathematics, School of Chemistry|accessdate=10 November 2015|page=127|format=Thesis|date=January 2010|chapter=Compound IX:hydrated ammonium zirconium arsenate}}</ref> |632.558 |10.532 |3.379 |}
==Selenates== Langbeinite structured double selenates are difficult to make, perhaps because selenate ions arranged around the dication leave space for water, so hydrates crystallise from double selenate solutions. For example, when ammonia selenate and cadmium selenate solution is crystallized it forms diammonium dicadmium selenate trihydrate: (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(SeO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>•3H<sub>2</sub>O and when heated it loses both water and ammonia to form a [[pyroselenate]] rather than a langeinite.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Martínez|first1=M.L.|last2=Rodriguez|first2=A.|last3=Mestres|first3=L.|last4=Solans|first4=X.|last5=Bocanegra|first5=E.H.|title=Synthesis, crystal structure, and thermal studies of (NH4)2Cd2(SeO4)3·3H2O|journal=Journal of Solid State Chemistry|date=November 1990|volume=89|issue=1|pages=88–93|doi=10.1016/0022-4596(90)90297-B|bibcode=1990JSSCh..89...88M}}</ref> {|class="wikitable" !substance !formula weight !unit cell edge Å !density !note |- |(NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Mn<sub>2</sub>(SeO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kohler|first1=K.|last2=Franke|first2=W.|title=(NH4)2Mn2(SeO4)3, Ein Doppelselenat mit Langbeiniestruktur|journal=Acta Crystallographica|date=1 August 1964|volume=17|issue=8|pages=1088–1089|doi=10.1107/s0365110x64002833|language=de}}</ref> |574.83 |10.53 |3.26 |forms continuous series with SO<sub>4</sub> too |}
==Molybdates== {|class="wikitable" !substance !formula weight !unit cell edge Å !density |- |Cs<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>2</sub>(MoO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name="Tsyrenova2011">{{cite journal|last=Tsyrenova|first=G. D.|author2=N. N. Pavlova |year=2011|title=Synthesis, structure, and electrical and acoustic properties of Cs2Cd<sub>2</sub>(MoO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Inorganic Materials|volume=47|issue=7|pages=786–790|doi=10.1134/S0020168511070235}}</ref> |970.5 |11.239 | |- |Rb<sub>2</sub>Co<sub>2</sub>(MoO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> |768.7 | | |- |Cs<sub>2</sub>Co<sub>2</sub>(MoO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Yudin |first1=Vasiliy N. |last2=Zolotova |first2=Evgeniya S. |last3=Solodovnikov |first3=Sergey F. |last4=Solodovnikova |first4=Zoya A. |last5=Korolkov |first5=Iliya V. |last6=Stefanovich |first6=Sergey Yu. |last7=Kuchumov |first7=Boris M. |title=Synthesis, structure and conductivity of alluaudite-related phases in the Na₂MoO₄-Cs₂MoO₄-CoMoO₄ system |journal=European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry |date=23 November 2018 |doi=10.1002/ejic.201801307}}</ref> | | | |- |Cs<sub>2</sub>Ni<sub>2</sub>(MoO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zolotova|first1=E. S.|last2=Solodovnikova|first2=Z. A.|last3=Ayupov|first3=B. M.|last4=Solodovnikov|first4=S. F.|title=Phase formation in the Li2MoO4-A2MoO4-NiMoO4 (A = K, Rb, Cs) systems, the crystal structure of Cs2Ni2(MoO4)3, and color characteristics of alkali-metal nickel molybdates|journal=Russian Journal of Inorganic Chemistry|date=16 August 2011|volume=56|issue=8|pages=1216–1221|doi=10.1134/S0036023611080298}}</ref> |863.01 |10.7538 |- |(H<sub>3</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>Mn<sub>2</sub>(MoO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Yu|first1=Yang|last2=Liu|first2=Dan|last3=Hu|first3=Wei-wei|last4=Li|first4=Jia|last5=Peng|first5=Yu|last6=Zhou|first6=Qi|last7=Yang|first7=Fen|last8=Li|first8=Guang-hua|last9=Shi|first9=Zhan|title=Synthesis, Structure and Characterization of Three Metal Molybdate Hydrates: Fe(H2O)2(MoO4)2·H3O, NaCo2(MoO4)2(H3O2) and Mn2(MoO4)3·2H3O|journal=Chem Res. Chinese Universities|date=2012|volume=28|issue=2|pages=186–190|url=http://www.cjcu.jlu.edu.cn/hxyj/EN/article/downloadArticleFile.do?attachType=PDF&id=15425|accessdate=10 November 2015}}</ref> |627.75 |1.08713 | |}
==Tungstates== {|class="wikitable" !substance !formula weight !unit cell edge Å !density |- |Rb<sub>2</sub>Mg<sub>2</sub>(WO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=Han15>{{cite journal|last1=Han|first1=Shujuan|last2=Wang|first2=Ying|last3=Jing|first3=Qun|last4=Wu|first4=Hongping|last5=Pan|first5=Shilie|last6=Yang|first6=Zhihua|title=Effect of the cation size on the framework structures of magnesium tungstate, A4Mg(WO4)3(A = Na, K), R2Mg2 (WO 4) 3 (R = Rb, Cs)|journal=Dalton Trans.|date=2015|volume=44|issue=12|pages=5810–5817|doi=10.1039/c5dt00332f|pmid=25715112}}</ref> |963.06 |10.766 | |- |Cs<sub>2</sub>Mg<sub>2</sub>(WO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><ref name=Han15/> |1057.93 |10.878 | |}
==Preparation== Diammonium dicadmium sulfate can be made by evaporating a solution of [[ammonium sulfate]] and [[cadmium sulfate]].<ref name="Moriyoshi"/> Dithallium dicadmium sulfate can be made by evaporating a water solution at 85 °C.<ref name="B̌rzina1972"/> Other substances may be formed during crystallisation from water such as [[Tutton's salts]] or competing compounds like Rb<sub>2</sub>Cd<sub>3</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub>·5H<sub>2</sub>O.<ref name="Swain2005">{{cite journal|last=Swain|first=Diptikanta|author2=T. N. Guru Row |year=2005|title=Dirubidium tricadmium tetrakis(sulfate) pentahydrate|journal=Acta Crystallographica Section E|volume=61|issue=8|pages=i163–i164|doi=10.1107/S1600536805021252|url=http://eprints.iisc.ernet.in/3645/1/A156.pdf}}</ref>
Potassium and ammonium nickel langbeinite can be made from nickel sulfate and the other sulfates by evaporating a water solution at 85 °C.<ref name="Jayakumar1995"/>
Dipotassium dizinc sulfate can be formed into large crystals by melting [[zinc sulfate]] and [[potassium sulfate]] together at 753K. A crystal can be slowly drawn out of the melt from a rotating crucible at about 1.2 mm every hour.<ref name="Yamada1981b">{{cite journal|last=Yamada|first=N.|author2=Tomoyuki Hikita |author3=Kazuhiro Yamada |year=1981|title=Pyroelectric properties of langbeinite-type K<sub>2</sub>Zn2(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>|journal=Ferroelectrics|volume=33|issue=1|pages=59–61|doi=10.1080/00150198108008070}}</ref>
Li(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>Hf<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> can be made by heating HfCl<sub>4</sub>, Li<sub>2</sub>B<sub>4</sub>O<sub>7</sub>, H<sub>3</sub>PO<sub>4</sub>, water and hydrochloric acid to 180 °C for eight days under pressure.<ref name="Chen11"/> Li(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>Hf<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> converts to Li<sub>2</sub>Hf<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> on heating to 200 °C.<ref name="Chen2011"/>
The sol-gel method produces a gel from a solution mixture, which is then heated. Rb<sub>2</sub>FeZr(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> can be made by mixing solutions of FeCl<sub>3</sub>, RbCl, ZrOCl<sub>2</sub>, and dripping in H<sub>3</sub>PO<sub>4</sub>. The gel produced was dried out at 95 °C and then baked at various temperatures from 400 to 1100 °C.<ref name="Trubach2004"/>
Langbeinites crystals can be made by the Bridgman technique, [[Czochralski process]] or flux technique.
A Tutton's salt may be heat treated and dehydrate, e.g. (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Mn<sub>2</sub>(SeO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> can be made from (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Mn(SeO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>·6(H<sub>2</sub>O) heated to 100 °C, forming (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(SeO<sub>4</sub>) as a side product.<ref name="Kohler1964">{{cite journal|last=Kohler|first=K.|author2=W. Franke |year=1964|title=(NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Mn<sub>2</sub>(SeO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, Ein Doppelselenat mit Langbeiniestruktur|journal=Acta Crystallographica|volume=17|issue=8|pages=1088–1089|doi=10.1107/S0365110X64002833}}</ref> Similarly the ammonium vandadium Tutton's salt, (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>V(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, heated to 160 °C in a closed tube produces (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. At lower temperatures a hydroxy compound is formed.<ref name=tudo/>
==Use== Few uses have been made of these substances. Lanbeinite itself can be used as an "organic" fertiliser with potassium, magnesium and sulfur, all needed for plant growth. Electrooptic devices could be made from some of these crystals, particularly those that have cubic transition temperatures as temperatures above room temperature. Research continues into this. Ferroelectric crystals could store information in the location of domain walls.
The phosphate langbeinites are insoluble, stable against heat, and can accommodate a large number of different ions, and have been considered for immobilizing unwanted [[radioactive waste]].<ref name="Orlova2006b">{{cite journal|last=Orlova|first=A. I.|author2=V. A. Orlova, M. P. Orlova, D. M. Bykov, S. V. Stefanovskii, O. I. Stefanovskaya, B. S. Nikonov|year=2006|title=The crystal-chemical principle in designing mineral-like phosphate ceramics for immobilization of radioactive waste|journal=Radiochemistry|volume=48|issue=4|pages=330–339|doi=10.1134/S1066362206040035}}</ref>
Rare earth containing zirconium phosphate langeinites have been investigated for use in white LEDs and plasma displays.<ref name=chornii15/> Langbeinites that contain bismuth are photoluminescent.<ref name=chornii15/> In case of iron-containing ones complex [[magnetic]] behavior may be found.<ref name="Slobodyanik">{{cite journal|last=Slobodyanik|first=M. S.|author2=N. S. Slobodyanik, K. V. Terebilenko, I. V. Ogorodnyk, I. V. Zatovsky, M. Seredyuk, V. N. Baumer, P. Gütlich|year=2012|title=K2MIII2(MVIO4)(PO4)2 (MIII = Fe, Sc; MVI = Mo, W), Novel Members of the Lagbeinite-Related Family: Synthesis, Structure, and Magnetic Properties|journal=Inorg. Chem.|volume=51|issue=5|pages=1380–1385|doi=10.1021/ic201575v|pmid=22260084}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
The '''Larson–Miller relation''', also widely known as the '''Larson–Miller parameter''' and often abbreviated '''LMP''', is a parametric relation used to extrapolate experimental data on [[creep (deformation)|creep]] and rupture life of engineering materials.
==Background and usage==
F.R. Larson and J. Miller proposed that creep rate could adequately be described by the [[Arrhenius_equation|Arrhenius type equation]]:
:<math>r = A \cdot e^{-\Delta H/(R \cdot T)}</math>
Where r is the creep process rate, A is a constant, R is the [[universal gas constant]], T is the [[absolute temperature]], and <math>\Delta H</math> is the [[activation energy]] for the creep process. Taking the natural log of both sides:
:<math>\ln(r) = \ln(A) - \Delta H/(R \cdot T)</math>
With some rearrangement:
:<math>\Delta H/R = T \cdot (\ln(A) - \ln(r))</math>
Using the fact that creep rate is inversely proportional to time, the equation can be written as:
:<math>\Delta l/\Delta t = A' \cdot e^{-\Delta H/ ( R \cdot T )}</math>
Taking the natural log:
:<math>\ln(\Delta l/\Delta t) = \ln(A') - \Delta H/(R \cdot T)</math>
After some rearrangement the relation finally becomes:
:<math>\Delta H/R = T \cdot (B + \ln(\Delta t))</math>, where B = <math>\ln(A'/\Delta l)</math>
This equation is of the same form as the Larson–Miller relation.
:<math>LMP = T \cdot (C + \log(t))</math>
where the quantity LMP is known as the Larson–Miller parameter. Using the assumption that activation energy is independent of applied stress, the equation can be used to relate the difference in rupture life to differences in temperature for a given stress. The material constant C is typically found to be in the range of 20 to 22 for metals when time is expressed in hours and temperature in degrees Rankine.
The Larson–Miller model is used for experimental tests so that results at certain temperatures and stresses can predict rupture lives of time spans that would be impractical to reproduce in the laboratory.
Expanding the equation as a Taylor series makes the relationship easier to understand. Only the first terms are kept. :<math>\Delta LMP = \frac{\partial LMP}{\partial T} \cdot \Delta T + \frac{\partial LMP}{\partial \log(t)} \cdot \Delta log(t) +\cdots</math> :<math>\frac{\partial LMP}{\partial T} = 20 + \log(t) \qquad \qquad \frac{\partial LMP}{\partial \log(t)} = T</math> Changing the time, by a factor of 10, changes the logarithm by 1 and the LMP changes by an amount equal to the temperature. :<math>\Delta LMP = \frac{\partial LMP}{\partial \log(t)} \cdot \Delta \log(t) = T \cdot \Delta \log(t) = T \cdot 1 = T </math> To get an equal change in LMP by changing the temperature, the temperature needs to be raised or lowered by about 5% of its absolute value. :<math>\Delta LMP = T = \frac{\partial LMP}{\partial T} \cdot \Delta T \qquad \Delta T = \frac{\Delta LMP}{\frac{\partial LMP}{\partial T}} = \frac{T}{(20+\log(t))} \approx \frac{T}{20} =5\% T</math> Typically a 5% increase in absolute temperature will increase the rate of creep by a factor of ten.
The equation was developed during the 1950s while Miller and Larson were employed by GE performing research on turbine blade life.
==See also== * [[Creep (deformation)]]
==References==
*Hertzberg, Richard W. Deformation and Fracture Mechanics of Engineering Materials, Fourth Edition. John Wiley and Sons, Inc., Hoboken, NJ: 1996. *Larson, Frank R. and Miller, James: A Time-Temperature Relationship for Rupture and Creep Stresses. Trans. ASME, vol. 74, pp. 765−775. * Fuchs, G. E. High Temperature Alloys, ''Kirk–Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology'' * Smith & Hashemi, ''Foundations of Material Science and Engineering'' * Dieter, G.E. ''Mechanical Metallurgy, Third Edition'', McGraw-Hill Inc., 1986, p 461-465, {{ISBN|0-07-016893-8}}.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Larson-Miller relation}} [[Category:Materials science]]

page.title: List of explosives used during World War II

revision.text:
Almost all the common explosives listed here were mixtures of several common components:
* [[Ammonium picrate]] * TNT ([[Trinitrotoluene]]) * PETN ([[Pentaerythritol tetranitrate]]) * [[RDX]] * Powdered [[aluminium]].
This is only a partial list; there were many others. Many of these compositions are now obsolete and only encountered in legacy munitions and unexploded ordnance.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Name !! Composition !! Notes |- | [[Amatol]]||Ammonium nitrate and TNT || Extensively used in bombs, shells, depth charges and naval mines |- | [[Baronal]]||[[Barium nitrate]], TNT and powdered aluminium || |- | [[Baratol (explosive)|Baratol]]||Barium nitrate and TNT ||Used in British hand grenades |- | [[Composition A]]||88.3% RDX and 11.7% [[plasticizer]] || |- | [[Composition B]]||RDX, TNT and [[wax]] || |- | [[Composition H6]]||45% RDX, 30% TNT, 20% powdered aluminium and 5% wax ||Replaced Torpex for use in naval applications. |- |DBX (Depth Bomb Explosive)||21% RDX, 21% ammonium nitrate, 40% TNT, 18% powdered aluminium ||An alternative for Torpex, that used less of the strategic material RDX |- | [[Minol (explosive)|Minol]]||40% TNT, 40% [[ammonium nitrate]] and 20% powdered aluminium (Minol-2) ||Developed by the British Royal Navy and used in torpedoes, depth charges and naval mines. Unsuitable for shells because of a risk of detonation if subjected to very high accelerations. |- | [[Octol]]||75% [[HMX]] (cyclotetramethylene-tetranitramine) and 25% TNT ||Still in use |- | [[Pentolite]]s||50% PETN and 50% TNT || |- | [[Picratol]]||52% [[ammonium picrate]] and 48% TNT ||Used in armour-piercing shells and bombs as insensitive to shock |- | [[PIPE (explosive)|PIPE]]||81% PETN and 19% [[petroleum|oil]] || |- | [[PTX-1]]||30% RDX, 50% [[tetryl]] and 20% TNT || |- | [[PTX-2]]||41-44% RDX, 26-28% PETN and 28-33% TNT || |- | [[PVA-4]]||90% RDX, 8% [[polyvinyl alcohol|PVA]] and 2% [[dibutyl phthalate]] || |- | [[RIPE (explosive)|RIPE]]||85% RDX and 15% oil || |- | [[Tetrytol]]s||70% [[Tetryl]] and 30% TNT || |- | [[Torpex]]||42% RDX, 40% TNT and 18% powdered aluminium ||Developed for use in torpedoes, it was especially effective at producing destructive, underwater explosions. |- | [[Trialen 105]]||15% RDX, 70% TNT and 15% powdered aluminium ||Used by the [[Luftwaffe]] |- |Explosive "D" |Ammonium picrate || US Army/Navy |- |Type 91 Explosive |Trinitroanisol (TNA) || Japanese Army/Navy |}
Two nuclear explosives, containing mixtures of uranium and plutonium, respectively, were also used at the bombings of [[Hiroshima]] and [[Nagasaki]]
==See also== *[[List of Japanese World War II explosives]] *[[Explosive material]] *[[Little Boy]] *[[Fat Man]]
[[Category:Explosives|*]] [[Category:World War II weapons|Explosives]]

revision.comment: Added free to read link in citations with [[WP:OABOT|OAbot]] #oabot
revision.text:
{{Unsolved|physics|Can we build materials that show properties of both ferromagnets and semiconductors at room temperature?}} '''Magnetic semiconductors''' are [[semiconductor material]]s that exhibit both [[ferromagnetism]] (or a similar response) and useful [[semiconductor]] properties. If implemented in devices, these materials could provide a new type of control of conduction. Whereas traditional electronics are based on control of [[charge carrier]]s ([[n-type semiconductor|n-]] or [[p-type semiconductor|p-type]]), practical magnetic semiconductors would also allow control of quantum [[spin (physics)|spin state]] (up or down). This would theoretically provide near-total [[spin polarization]] (as opposed to [[iron]] and other metals, which provide only ~50% polarization), which is an important property for [[spintronics]] applications, e.g. [[spin transistor]]s.
While many traditional magnetic materials, such as [[magnetite]], are also semiconductors (magnetite is a [[semimetal]] semiconductor with [[bandgap]] 0.14 eV), materials scientists generally predict that magnetic semiconductors will only find widespread use if they are similar to well-developed semiconductor materials. To that end, '''dilute magnetic semiconductors''' ('''DMS''') have recently been a major focus of magnetic semiconductor research. These are based on traditional semiconductors, but are [[doping (semiconductors)|doped]] with [[transition metal]]s instead of, or in addition to, electronically active elements. They are of interest because of their unique [[spintronics]] properties with possible technological applications.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Furdyna | first1 = J.K. | year = 1988 | title = Diluted magnetic semiconductors| url = | journal = J. Appl. Phys. | volume = 64 | issue = | page = R29 | doi=10.1063/1.341700 | bibcode=1988JAP....64...29F}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Ohno | first1 = H. | year = 1998 | title = Making Nonmagnetic Semiconductors Ferromagnetic| url = | journal = Science | volume = 281 | issue = | page = 951 | doi=10.1126/science.281.5379.951 | pmid=9703503| bibcode =1998Sci...281..951O}}</ref> Doped [[wide bandgap semiconductors|Wide band-gap]] metal oxides such as [[zinc oxide]] (ZnO) and [[titanium oxide]] (TiO<sub>2</sub>) are among the best candidates for industrial DMS due to their multifunctionality in [[magnetooptics|opticomagnetic]] applications. In particular, ZnO-based DMS with properties such as transparency in visual region and [[piezoelectricity]] have generated huge interest among the scientific community as a strong candidate for the fabrication of [[spin transistor]]s and [[spin polarization|spin-polarized]] [[light-emitting diode]]s,<ref>{{cite journal| last1=Ogale| first1=S.B| title= Dilute doping, defects, and ferromagnetism in metal oxide systems.| journal= Advanced Materials| year=2010| volume=22| issue=29| pages= 3125–3155.| doi=10.1002/adma.200903891| pmid=20535732}}</ref> while [[copper]] doped TiO<sub>2</sub> in the [[anatase]] phase of this material has further been predicted to exhibit favorable dilute magnetism.<ref name="DMS">{{cite journal | last1=Assadi | first1=M.H.N | last2=Hanaor | first2=D.A.H | title= Theoretical study on copper's energetics and magnetism in TiO<sub>2</sub> polymorphs| journal= Journal of Applied Physics | year=2013 | volume=113 | issue=23 | pages= 233913 |url=https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1304/1304.1854.pdf| doi=10.1063/1.4811539| arxiv=1304.1854 | bibcode=2013JAP...113w3913A }}</ref>
[[Hideo Ohno]] and his group at the [[Tohoku University]] were the first to measure [[ferromagnetism]] in transition metal [[doping (semiconductors)|doped]] [[compound semiconductors]] such as [[indium arsenide]] and [[gallium arsenide]] doped with [[manganese]] referred to as [[GaMnAs]]. These materials exhibited reasonably high [[Curie temperature]]s (yet below [[room temperature]]) that scales with the concentration of [[P-type semiconductor|p-type]] charge carriers. Ever since, ferromagnetic signals have been measured from various semiconductor hosts doped with different transition atoms.
==Theory== The pioneering work of Dietl ''et al.'' showed that a modified Zener model for magnetism<ref name=dietl>{{cite journal | last1 = Dietl | first1 = T. | last2 = Ohno | first2 = H. | last3 = Matsukura | first3 = F. | last4 = Cibert | first4 = J. | last5 = Ferrand | first5 = D. | year = | title = Zener model description of ferromagnetism in zinc-blende magnetic semiconductors | url = | journal = Science | volume = 287 | issue = | page = 1019 | doi=10.1126/science.287.5455.1019 | pmid=10669409 | date=February 2000| bibcode = 2000Sci...287.1019D }}</ref> well describes the carrier dependence, as well as anisotropic properties of [[GaMnAs]]. The same theory also predicted that room-temperature [[ferromagnetism]] should exist in heavily [[p-type semiconductor|p-type]] [[doping (semiconductors)|doped]] ZnO and GaN doped by Co and Mn, respectively. These predictions were followed of a flurry of theoretical and experimental studies of various oxide and nitride semiconductors, which apparently seemed to confirm room temperature ferromagnetism in nearly any semiconductor or insulator material heavily doped by [[transition metal]] impurities. However, early [[Density functional theory]] (DFT) studies were clouded by band gap errors and overly delocalized defect levels, and more advanced DFT studies refute most of the previous predictions of ferromagnetism.<ref name=zunger> {{cite journal |author=Alex Zunger, Stephan Lany and Hannes Raebiger |title=The quest for dilute ferromagnetism in semiconductors: Guides and misguides by theory |year=2010 |journal=[[Physics]] |volume=3 |pages=53 |doi=10.1103/Physics.3.53|bibcode=2010PhyOJ...3...53Z}} </ref> Likewise, it has been shown that for most of the oxide based materials studies for magnetic semiconductors do not exhibit an intrinsic ''carrier-mediated'' ferromagnetism as postulated by Dietl ''et al.''<ref name=coey> {{cite journal |author=J. M. D. Coey, P. Stamenov, R. D. Gunning, M. Venkatesan, and K. Paul |title=Ferromagnetism in defect-ridden oxides and related materials |year=2010 |journal=[[New Journal of Physics]] |volume=12 |pages=053025 |doi=10.1088/1367-2630/12/5/053025|arxiv=1003.5558|bibcode=2010NJPh...12e3025C}} </ref> To date, [[GaMnAs]] remains the only semiconductor material with robust coexistence of ferromagnetism persisting up to rather high Curie temperatures around 100–200 K.
==Materials== {{Refimprove|date=July 2007}}
The manufacturability of the materials depend on the thermal equilibrium [[solubility]] of the [[dopant]] in the base material. E.g., solubility of many dopants in [[zinc oxide]] is high enough to prepare the materials in bulk, while some other materials have so low solubility of dopants that to prepare them with high enough dopant concentration thermal nonequilibrium preparation mechanisms have to be employed, e.g. growth of [[thin film]]s.
Permanent magnetization has been observed in a wide range of semiconductor based materials. Some of them exhibit a clear correlation between [[carrier density|carrier concentration]] and magnetization, including the work of T. Story and co-workers where they demonstrated that the ferromagnetic Curie temperature of [[manganese|Mn<sup>2+</sup>]]-doped [[lead tin telluride|Pb<sub>1−x</sub>Sn<sub>x</sub>Te]] can be controlled by the [[carrier density|carrier concentration]].<ref name=story> {{cite journal |last1=Story |first1=T. |last2=Gała̧zka|first2=R. |last3=Frankel|first3=R. |last4=Wolff|first4=P. |title=Carrier-concentration–induced ferromagnetism in PbSnMnTe |journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |volume=56|issue=7|page=777 |year=1986 |doi= 10.1103/PhysRevLett.56.777 |bibcode = 1986PhRvL..56..777S |pmid=10033282}}</ref> The theory proposed by Dietl required [[charge carriers in semiconductors|charge carriers]] in the case of [[electron hole|holes]] to mediate the [[magnetic coupling]] of manganese [[dopant]]s in the prototypical magnetic semiconductor, Mn<sup>2+</sup>-doped [[GaAs]]. If there is an insufficient hole concentration in the magnetic semiconductor, then the [[Curie temperature]] would be very low or would exhibit only [[paramagnetism]]. However, if the hole concentration is high (<nowiki>></nowiki>~10<sup>20</sup> cm<sup>−3</sup>), then the [[Curie temperature]] would be higher, between 100–200 K. <ref name=dietl></ref> However, many of the semiconductor materials studied exhibit a permanent magnetization ''extrinsic'' to the semiconductor host material.<ref name=coey></ref> A lot of the elusive extrinsic ferromagnetism (or ''phantom ferromagnetism'') is observed in thin films or nanostructured materials.<ref name=pereira> {{cite journal |author=L. M. C. Pereira |title=Experimentally evaluating the origin of dilute magnetism in nanomaterials |year=2017 |journal=[[Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics]] |volume=50 |pages=393002 |doi=10.1088/1361-6463/aa801f|bibcode=2017JPhD...50M3002P}} </ref>
Several examples of ferromagnetic semiconductor materials are e.g.:
* [[Manganese]]-doped [[indium arsenide]] and [[gallium arsenide]] ([[GaMnAs]]), with Curie temperature around 50–100 K and 100–200 K, respectively * Manganese-doped [[indium antimonide]], which becomes ferromagnetic even at room temperature and even with less than 1% Mn.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.triumf.info/public/news/newsletter/V3N2/Muons.htm |title=Muons in Magnetic Semiconductors |publisher=Triumf.info |date= |accessdate=2010-09-19}}</ref> * Oxide semiconductors<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fukumura |first1=T |last2=Toyosaki |first2=H |last3=Yamada |first3=Y |title=Magnetic oxide semiconductors |journal=Semiconductor Science and Technology |volume=20 |issue=4 |pages=S103–S111 |year=2005 |doi=10.1088/0268-1242/20/4/012|arxiv = cond-mat/0504168 |bibcode = 2005SeScT..20S.103F }}</ref> ** Manganese- and [[iron]]-doped [[indium oxide]], ferromagnetic at room temperature ** [[Zinc oxide]] *** Manganese-doped [[zinc oxide]] *** [[n-type semiconductor|n-type]] cobalt-doped [[zinc oxide]]<ref> {{cite journal |last1=Kittilstved |first1=Kevin |last2=Schwartz |first2=Dana |last3=Tuan |first3=Allan |last4=Heald |first4=Steve |last5=Chambers |first5=Scott |last6=Gamelin |first6=Daniel |title=Direct Kinetic Correlation of Carriers and Ferromagnetism in Co2+: ZnO |journal=Physical Review Letters |volume=97 |issue=3 |year=2006 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.97.037203|bibcode = 2006PhRvL..97c7203K |url=https://works.bepress.com/kevin_kittilstved/4/download/ }}</ref> *** Lanthanide-doped zinc oxide<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Caroena|first1=G.|last2=Machado|first2=W. V. M.|last3=Justo|first3=J. F.|last4=Assali|first4=L. V. C.|title=Lanthanide impurities in wide bandgap semiconductors: a possible roadmap for spintronic devices|journal=Appl. Phys. Lett.|date=2013|volume=102|page=062101|doi=10.1063/1.4791787|arxiv=1307.3209|bibcode=2013ApPhL.102f2101C}}</ref> ** [[Magnesium oxide]]: *** [[P-type semiconductor|p-type]] transparent MgO films with cation vacancies,<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Ferromagnetism in transparent thin films of MgO|url = http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.82.024405|journal = Physical Review B|date = 2010-07-08|pages = 024405|volume = 82|issue = 2|doi = 10.1103/PhysRevB.82.024405|first = C.|last = Martínez-Boubeta|first2 = J. I.|last2 = Beltrán|first3 = Ll.|last3 = Balcells|first4 = Z.|last4 = Konstantinović|first5 = S.|last5 = Valencia|first6 = D.|last6 = Schmitz|first7 = J.|last7 = Arbiol|first8 = S.|last8 = Estrade|first9 = J.|last9 = Cornil|bibcode = 2010PhRvB..82b4405M }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Resistance switching in transparent magnetic MgO films|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S003810981100545X|journal = Solid State Communications|date = 2011-12-01|pages = 1856–1859|volume = 151|issue = 24|doi = 10.1016/j.ssc.2011.10.009|first = O.|last = Jambois|first2 = P.|last2 = Carreras|first3 = A.|last3 = Antony|first4 = J.|last4 = Bertomeu|first5 = C.|last5 = Martínez-Boubeta|bibcode = 2011SSCom.151.1856J }}</ref> combining ferromagnetism and multilevel switching ([[memristor]]) ** [[Titanium dioxide]]: *** [[Cobalt]]-doped [[titanium dioxide]] (both [[rutile]] and [[anatase]]), ferromagnetic above 400 [[kelvin|K]] *** [[Chromium]]-doped [[rutile]], ferromagnetic above 400 [[kelvin|K]] *** [[Iron]]-doped rutile and iron-doped anatase, ferromagnetic at room temperature *** [[Copper]]-doped [[anatase]]<ref name="DMS" /> *** [[Nickel]]-doped [[anatase]] ** [[Tin dioxide]] *** Manganese-doped [[tin dioxide]], with Curie temperature at 340 K *** Iron-doped [[tin dioxide]], with Curie temperature at 340 K *** Strontium-doped tin dioxide ({{chem|SrSnO|2}}) – Dilute magnetic semiconductor. Can be synthesized an [[epitaxial]] thin film on a silicon chip.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kurzweilai.net/new-room-temperature-magnetic-semiconductor-material-holds-promise-for-spintronics-data-storage-devices |title=New room-temperature magnetic semiconductor material holds promise for ‘spintronics’ data-storage devices |publisher=KurzweilAI |date= |accessdate=2013-09-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Lee | first1 = Y. F. | last2 = Wu | first2 = F. | last3 = Kumar | first3 = R. | last4 = Hunte | first4 = F. | last5 = Schwartz | first5 = J. | last6 = Narayan | first6 = J. | doi = 10.1063/1.4820770 | title = Epitaxial integration of dilute magnetic semiconductor Sr3SnO with Si (001) | journal = Applied Physics Letters | volume = 103 | issue = 11 | pages = 112101 | year = 2013 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 2013ApPhL.103k2101L }}</ref> ** Europium oxide, with a Curie temperature of 69K. The curie temperature can be more than doubled by doping (e.g. oxygen deficiency, Gd). *[[Nitride]] semiconductors ** Chromium doped [[aluminium nitride]]<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Chambers |first1=Scott A. |title=Epitaxial Growth and Properties of Doped Transition Metal and Complex Oxide Films |journal=Advanced Materials |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=219–248 |year=2010 |pmid=20217685 |doi=10.1002/adma.200901867}}</ref> ** Manganese doped gallium nitride and boron nitride<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Assali|first1=L. V. C.|last2=Machado|first2=W. V. M.|last3=Justo|first3=J. F.|title=Manganese impurities in boron nitride|journal=Appl. Phys. Lett.|date=2006|volume=89|issue=7|page=072102|doi=10.1063/1.2266930|bibcode=2006ApPhL..89g2102A}}</ref>
==External links== {{Reflist}} * {{cite journal |last1=Cabot |first1=Andreu |last2=Puntes |first2=Victor F. |last3=Shevchenko |first3=Elena |last4=Yin |first4=Yadong |last5=Balcells |first5=Lluís |last6=Marcus |first6=Matthew A. |last7=Hughes |first7=Steven M. |last8=Alivisatos |first8=A. Paul |doi=10.1021/ja072574a |title=Vacancy Coalescence during Oxidation of Iron Nanoparticles |pmid=17676738 |year=2007 |pages=10358–10360 |issue=34 |volume=129 |journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society |url=http://xraysweb.lbl.gov/uxas/Publicatons/Papers/pdfs/cabot%20FeNanos.pdf}} * {{cite journal |last1=Chambers |first1=Scott A. |title=Epitaxial Growth and Properties of Doped Transition Metal and Complex Oxide Films |journal=Advanced Materials |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=219–248 |year=2010 |pmid=20217685 |doi=10.1002/adma.200901867}}

revision.text:
The '''Marshall Super Lead''' Model 1959 is a [[guitar amplifier]] head made by [[Marshall Amplification|Marshall]]. One of the famous Marshall Plexis, it was introduced in 1965 and with its associated 4×12" cabinets gave rise to the "Marshall stack".
==History== The 1959 (Marshall's identifying numbers are not years of manufacture) was produced from 1965 to 1981 (when it was replaced by the [[Marshall JCM800|JCM800]]),<ref name="blue">{{cite book|last=Blue Book of Guitar Amplifiers|first=Zachary R.|title=Blue Book of Guitar Amplifiers|publisher=Alfred Music|year=2008|volume=3|pages=335–36|isbn=978-1-886768-59-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pKCYz1WfZCQC&pg=PA335}}</ref> is an amplifier in Marshall's "Standard" series.<ref name="boehnlein">{{cite book|last=Boehnlein|first=John|title=The High Performance Marshall Handbook: A Guide to Great Marshall Amplifier Sounds|publisher=Bold Strummer|year=1998|pages=3–5|isbn=978-0-933224-80-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vm00dXNS30IC&pg=PA3}}</ref> It was designed by Ken Bran and Dudley Craven after [[The Who]]'s guitarist [[Pete Townshend]] asked Marshall for a 100 watt amplifier.<ref name="pittman">{{cite book|last=Pittmann|first=Aspen|title=The Tube Amp Book|publisher=Hal Leonard|year=2003|pages=72–74|isbn=978-0-87930-767-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JT1I7Ld76YsC&pg=PA72}}</ref> Its output was first channeled into an 8×12" cabinet, but that single, unwieldy cabinet was quickly changed to a pair of 4x12" cabinets, 1960a "angled" on top and 1960b "box" on bottom. creating the famous "Marshall full stack".<ref name="millard">{{cite book|last=Millard|first=A.J.|title=The Electric Guitar: A History of an American Icon|publisher=JHU Press|year=2004|pages=155|isbn=978-0-8018-7862-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zUlt7Q71_ssC&pg=PA155}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Doyle|first=Michael|title=The History of Marshall: The Illustrated Story of "The Sound of Rock"|publisher=Hal Leonard|year=1993|pages=37|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E90tMBs9_FEC&pg=PA37|isbn=9780793525096}}</ref> The amplifier also came as a [[Public address|PA]] and a [[Bass guitar|bass]] version.<ref name="blue"/>
The [[Poly(methyl methacrylate)|Plexiglas]] panel led to the name "Plexi", and while 50-watt models of the time are also called Plexis,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Molenda|first=Michael|date=June 2008|title=The Homogenization of Rock Guitar Tone|journal=[[Guitar Player]]|volume=42|issue=6|pages=76–78}}</ref> the 1959 100 watt model is generally thought of as the "definitive" Plexi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicradar.com/gear/all/amplification/instrument-amps/guitar-amp-heads/bc-50-head-179578/review|title=Bad Cat BC 50|last=Guppy|first=Nick|date=3 November 2008|publisher=[[MusicRadar]]|accessdate=16 April 2010}}</ref>
In 1969, Marshall replaced the Plexiglas panel with one of gold aluminum.<ref name="blue"/> There were other modifications: In 1966, the [[KT66]] tubes of the JTM-models were replaced with [[EL34]]. After 1976, the plate voltages were lowered slightly for improved reliability. But during the 1970s, Marshall's increasing exports overseas led to a problem: Often the EL34 tubes would break during transportation, to the point where amps began being shipped from the factory with more rugged [[Tung-Sol]] [[6550]] tubes, which are "stiffer and not as harmonically rich" as the EL34 tubes.<ref name="pittman"/>
===Reissues=== The amplifier was reissued for the first time in 1988 (the 1959S), and again from 1991 to 1993 (the 1959X) and from 1993 to 1995 (the 1959 SLP).<ref name="blue" /> In 2005, Marshall introduced the 1959 HW (for "hand-wired"), based on the 1967–1969 models, with negative feedback added corresponding to the 1969 model.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marshallamps.com/downloads/files/1959HW%20hbk.pdf|title=Marshall 1959HW Owner's Manual|publisher=[[Marshall Amplification]]|pages=1, 3|accessdate=16 April 2010}}</ref> This amplifier was called "expensive but good".<ref name="balmer" /> ''[[Guitar Player]]'' magazine called the 1959 "monumentally huge, frightfully loud, and painfully expensive", and its review of the 1959HW said it was "quick, percussive, articulate", and required a "total commitment to volume".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Buddingh|first=Terry|date=December 2005|title=Marshall 1959HW Super Lead 100|journal=[[Guitar Player]]|volume=39|issue=12|pages=176–78}}</ref>
==Technical specifications== The 1959 had 100 watts of power, two channels, and four inputs. They were equipped with 4x KT66 tubes, but models made after 1967 had four EL34 tubes instead; it had three [[12AX7|ECC83]] tubes in the [[pre-amplifier|pre-amplification]] stage. A model with [[tremolo]], the 1959T, was available until 1973.<ref name="blue"/>
The amplifier had four inputs into two channels. The lead channel has a boosted bright tone, and the rhythm channel has a flat response. Each channel has a high and a low gain input; the low gain input is attenuated by 6 dB.<ref name="boehnlein"/> The channels can be linked with a jumper cable.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marshallamps.com/downloads/files/1959HW%20hbk.pdf|title=Marshall 1959HW Owner's Manual|publisher=[[Marshall Amplification]]|pages=6|accessdate=16 April 2010}}</ref>
==Notable early users== Besides Pete Townshend of [[The Who]], early users include [[Eric Clapton]], who in 1966, when he founded [[Cream (band)|Cream]], traded in his famous [[Marshall Bluesbreaker|Bluesbreaker]] combo for a 1959 Plexi,<ref>{{cite book|last=Gulla|first=Bob|title=Guitar Gods: The 25 Players Who Made Rock History|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=2008|pages=46|isbn=978-0-313-35806-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DL3I9qQWdeAC&pg=PA46}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Hunter|first=Dave|title=Guitar Rigs: Classic Guitar & Amp Combinations|publisher=Backbeat|isbn=9780879308513|year=2005|pages=113|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p1-kULtG9tgC&pg=PT113}}</ref> and [[Jimi Hendrix]], who used a 1959 with four 4×12" cabinets (his "couple of great refrigerators") at the 1969 [[Woodstock Festival]]<ref name="balmer">{{cite book|last=Balmer|first=Paul|author2=Hank Marvin |title=The Fender Stratocaster Handbook: How to Buy, Maintain, Set Up, Troubleshoot, and Modify Your Strat|publisher=MBI|year=2007|pages=156–57|isbn=978-0-7603-2983-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EiySv-2E8tUC&pg=PA156}}</ref> and established the Marshall as the "definitive rock amp".<ref>{{cite book|last=Trynka|first=Paul|title=Rock Hardware|publisher=Hal Leonard|year=1996|pages=19|isbn=978-0-87930-428-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HDrIjd5FQ8QC&pg=RA19}}</ref>
===Other notable users=== * [[John Frusciante]] * [[Angus Young]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Prown|first=Pete|title=Gear Secrets of the Guitar Legends: How to Sound Like Your Favorite Players|year=2003|publisher=Hal Leonard|isbn=978-0-87930-751-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vqQjuzPrqIwC&pg=PA2|author2=Lisa Sharken |page=2}}</ref> * [[Eddie Van Halen]]<ref>http://ultimateclassicrock.com/eddie-van-halen-reveals-his-biggest-lie/</ref> * [[Billie Joe Armstrong]] * [[Jason White (musician)|Jason White]] * [[Jimi Hendrix]] * [[Graham Coxon]] * [[Jimmy Page]] * [[Johnny Ramone]] * [[Pete Townshend]] * [[Ace Frehley]] * [[Billy Gibbons]] * [[J Mascis]] * [[Matt Bellamy]]<ref>https://marshallamps.com/artists/m/muse-matt-bellamy/</ref> * [[Randy Rhoads]] * [[Yngwie Malmsteen]] * [[George Lynch (musician)|George Lynch]] * [[Uli Jon Roth]] * [[Richie Kotzen]] * [[Slash (musician)|Slash]] * [[Neil Young]] * [[Richie Blackmore]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.juliensauctions.com/auctions/2017/neil-young/flipbook/194/|title=Property from the Collection of Neil Young|publisher=[[Julien's Auctions]]|accessdate=8 December 2017}}</ref> * Aarseth Oystein (Euronymous) Gabriel Almeda
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{Marshall amplifiers}}
